sn22.80:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sakkesu viharati kapilavatthusmiṃ nigrodhārāme.
sn22.80:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.

sn22.80:1.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavā kismiñcideva pakaraṇe bhikkhusaṅghaṃ paṇāmetvā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya kapilavatthuṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
sn22.80:1.2.eng: Then the Buddha, having dismissed the mendicant Saṅgha for some reason, robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Kapilavatthu for alms.
sn22.80:1.2.comm: Elsewhere, the reason is that the monks are too noisy (MN 67:4.6, Ud 3.3:4.1).

sn22.80:1.3.pli: Kapilavatthusmiṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto yena mahāvanaṃ tenupasaṅkami divāvihārāya.
sn22.80:1.3.eng: He wandered for alms in Kapilavatthu. After the meal, on his return from almsround, he went to the Great Wood for the day’s meditation,

sn22.80:1.4.pli: Mahāvanaṃ ajjhogāhetvā beluvalaṭṭhikāya mūle divāvihāraṃ nisīdi.
sn22.80:1.4.eng: plunged deep into it, and sat at the root of a young wood-apple tree to meditate.

sn22.80:2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavato rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
sn22.80:2.1.eng: Then as he was in private retreat this thought came to his mind,

sn22.80:2.2.comm: Pabāḷha (“purged”) is unique in this context. Compare Sanskrit pravāhana, “driving out, evacuation”.

sn22.80:2.3.pli: Santettha bhikkhū navā acirapabbajitā adhunāgatā imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ.
sn22.80:2.3.eng: But there are mendicants here who are junior, recently gone forth, newly come to this teaching and training.

sn22.80:2.4.pli: Tesaṃ mamaṃ apassantānaṃ siyā aññathattaṃ siyā vipariṇāmo.
sn22.80:2.4.eng: Not seeing me they may change and fall apart.

sn22.80:2.5.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma vacchassa taruṇassa mātaraṃ apassantassa siyā aññathattaṃ siyā vipariṇāmo;
sn22.80:2.5.eng: If a young calf doesn’t see its mother it may change and fall apart. …

sn22.80:2.6.pli: evameva santettha bhikkhū navā acirapabbajitā adhunāgatā imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ tesaṃ mamaṃ apassantānaṃ siyā aññathattaṃ siyā vipariṇāmo.

sn22.80:2.7.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma bījānaṃ taruṇānaṃ udakaṃ alabhantānaṃ siyā aññathattaṃ siyā vipariṇāmo;
sn22.80:2.7.eng: Or if young seedlings don’t get water they may change and fall apart.

sn22.80:2.8.eng: In the same way, there are mendicants here who are junior, recently gone forth, newly come to this teaching and training.

sn22.80:2.9.pli: tesaṃ mamaṃ alabhantānaṃ dassanāya siyā aññathattaṃ siyā vipariṇāmo.
sn22.80:2.9.eng: Not seeing me they may change and fall apart.

sn22.80:2.10.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ yatheva mayā pubbe bhikkhusaṅgho anuggahito, evameva etarahi anuggaṇheyyaṃ bhikkhusaṅghan”ti.
sn22.80:2.10.eng: Why don’t I support the mendicant Saṅgha now as I did in the past?”

sn22.80:3.1.pli: Atha kho brahmā sahampati bhagavato cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evameva—brahmaloke antarahito bhagavato purato pāturahosi.
sn22.80:3.1.eng: Then the divinity Sahampati knew what the Buddha was thinking. As easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, he vanished from the realm of divinity and reappeared in front of the Buddha.

sn22.80:3.2.pli: Atha kho brahmā sahampati ekaṃsaṃ uttarāsaṅgaṃ karitvā yena bhagavā tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn22.80:3.2.eng: He arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and said:

sn22.80:3.3.eng: “That’s so true, Blessed One! That’s so true, Holy One!

sn22.80:3.4.eng: The Buddha has purged the mendicant Saṅgha.

sn22.80:3.5.pli: Santettha bhikkhū navā acirapabbajitā adhunāgatā imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ.
sn22.80:3.5.eng: But there are mendicants who are junior, recently gone forth, newly come to this teaching and training. …

sn22.80:3.6.pli: Tesaṃ bhagavantaṃ apassantānaṃ siyā aññathattaṃ siyā vipariṇāmo.

sn22.80:3.7.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma vacchassa taruṇassa mātaraṃ apassantassa siyā aññathattaṃ siyā vipariṇāmo;

sn22.80:3.8.pli: evameva santettha bhikkhū navā acirapabbajitā adhunāgatā imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ tesaṃ bhagavantaṃ apassantānaṃ siyā aññathattaṃ siyā vipariṇāmo.

sn22.80:3.9.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma bījānaṃ taruṇānaṃ udakaṃ alabhantānaṃ siyā aññathattaṃ siyā vipariṇāmo;

sn22.80:3.10.pli: evameva santettha bhikkhū navā acirapabbajitā adhunāgatā imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ, tesaṃ bhagavantaṃ alabhantānaṃ dassanāya siyā aññathattaṃ siyā vipariṇāmo.

sn22.80:3.11.eng: May the Buddha be happy with the mendicant Saṅgha!

sn22.80:3.12.eng: May the Buddha welcome the mendicant Saṅgha!

sn22.80:3.13.pli: Yatheva bhagavatā pubbe bhikkhusaṅgho anuggahito, evameva etarahi anuggaṇhātu bhikkhusaṅghan”ti.
sn22.80:3.13.eng: May the Buddha support the mendicant Saṅgha now as he did in the past!”

sn22.80:4.2.pli: Atha kho brahmā sahampati bhagavato adhivāsanaṃ viditvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā tatthevantaradhāyi.
sn22.80:4.2.eng: Then the divinity Sahampati, knowing that the Buddha had consented, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before vanishing right there.

sn22.80:5.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yena nigrodhārāmo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
sn22.80:5.1.eng: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and went to the Banyan Tree Monastery, where he sat on the seat spread out.

sn22.80:5.2.pli: Nisajja kho bhagavā tathārūpaṃ iddhābhisaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkhāsi yathā te bhikkhū ekadvīhikāya sārajjamānarūpā yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkameyyuṃ.
sn22.80:5.2.eng: Then he used his psychic power to will that the mendicants would come to him timidly, alone or in pairs.

sn22.80:5.3.pli: Tepi bhikkhū ekadvīhikāya sārajjamānarūpā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinne kho te bhikkhū bhagavā etadavoca:
sn22.80:5.3.eng: Those mendicants approached the Buddha timidly, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to them:

sn22.80:6.1.eng: “This is the last of lifestyles, mendicants, namely relying on alms.
sn22.80:6.1.comm: The unusual use of anta here is, I believe, a play on words. Per the commentary, it suggests the “least” of lifestyles, but it is also that which “makes an end” of suffering and future lives, as said just a few sentences below.

sn22.80:6.2.pli: Abhisāpoyaṃ, bhikkhave, lokasmiṃ piṇḍolo vicarasi pattapāṇīti.
sn22.80:6.2.eng: The world curses you: ‘You beggar, walking bowl in hand!’

sn22.80:6.3.pli: Tañca kho etaṃ, bhikkhave, kulaputtā upenti atthavasikā, atthavasaṃ paṭicca;
sn22.80:6.3.eng: Yet earnest gentlemen take it up for a good reason.
sn22.80:6.3.comm: At Pvr 14:3.1, someone who is atthavasika is acting from the earnest intention for a god outcome.

sn22.80:6.4.pli: neva rājābhinītā, na corābhinītā, na iṇaṭṭā, na bhayaṭṭā, na ājīvikāpakatā;
sn22.80:6.4.eng: Not to escape a summons by a king or a summons for a bandit, or because you were in debt or in fear, or in order to make a living.
sn22.80:6.4.comm: The terms here follow the same sequence as in the Vinaya account of ordination. Generally, ordination should not be given in such cases, but if it is given, those performing it incur an offense of wrong-doing. | Soldiers joined the Sangha to escape military service, so the Buddha said one should not ordain those in service to a king (Kd 1:40.1.1). | Several rules regarding ordination of criminals were passed, the thrust of which is that wanted outlaws should not be ordained (Kd 1:41.1.1). | Another man ordained to escape debt (Kd 1:46.1.1). | Seventeen boys ordained as novices to get a nice livelihood (Kd 1:49.1.1). | The only item that does not straightforwardly correspond is “in fear” (bhayaṭṭa). In the Vinaya sequence, the ordination of slaves appears at this point (Kd 1:47.1.1). The connection is suggested by the verses of the water-carrier Puṇṇikā, who speaks of living “in fear” of her masters’ abuse and beatings (Thig 12.1:1.1).

sn22.80:6.5.pli: api ca kho otiṇṇāmha jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi dukkhotiṇṇā dukkhaparetā
sn22.80:6.5.eng: But because they’re swamped by rebirth, old age, and death; by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. They’re swamped by suffering, mired in suffering.

sn22.80:6.6.pli: appeva nāma imassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa antakiriyā paññāyethāti.
sn22.80:6.6.eng: And they think, ‘Hopefully I can make an end to this entire mass of suffering.’

sn22.80:7.1.eng: That’s how this gentleman has gone forth.

sn22.80:7.2.pli: So ca hoti abhijjhālu kāmesu tibbasārāgo byāpannacitto paduṭṭhamanasaṅkappo muṭṭhassati asampajāno asamāhito vibbhantacitto pākatindriyo.
sn22.80:7.2.eng: Yet they covet sensual pleasures; they’re infatuated, full of ill will and malicious intent. They are unmindful, lacking situational awareness and immersion, with straying mind and undisciplined faculties.

sn22.80:7.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, chavālātaṃ ubhatopadittaṃ majjhe gūthagataṃ, neva gāme kaṭṭhatthaṃ pharati, nāraññe kaṭṭhatthaṃ pharati.
sn22.80:7.3.eng: Suppose there was a firebrand for lighting a funeral pyre, burning at both ends, and smeared with dung in the middle. It couldn’t be used as timber either in the village or the wilderness.

sn22.80:7.4.pli: Tathūpamāhaṃ, bhikkhave, imaṃ puggalaṃ vadāmi gihibhogā ca parihīno, sāmaññatthañca na paripūreti.
sn22.80:7.4.eng: I say that individual is just like this. They’ve missed out on the pleasures of the lay life, and haven’t fulfilled the goal of the ascetic life.

sn22.80:8.1.eng: There are these three unskillful thoughts.

sn22.80:8.3.pli: Ime ca bhikkhave, tayo akusalavitakkā kva aparisesā nirujjhanti?
sn22.80:8.3.eng: And where do these three unskillful thoughts cease without anything left over?

sn22.80:8.4.pli: Catūsu vā satipaṭṭhānesu suppatiṭṭhitacittassa viharato animittaṃ vā samādhiṃ bhāvayato.
sn22.80:8.4.eng: In those who meditate with their mind firmly established in the four kinds of mindfulness meditation; or who develop signless immersion.
sn22.80:8.4.comm: The “signless” (animitta) meditation is described in the canon simply as, “not focusing on any signs, one enters and remains in the signless immersion of the heart” (SN 41.7:5.2, MN 43:27.2). The current passage distinguishes it from the four satipaṭṭhānas, which are called the “bases of immersion”, namely, the things on which you focus in order to achieve absorption (samādhinimitta, MN 44:12.3, cf. AN 4.14:4.2). Apparently the “signless” (or “baseless” or “featureless”) meditation proceeds without any such meditation topic. At its deepest level, it focuses on the absence of the signs of greed, hatred, and delusion (SN 41.7:6.10). Compare the “undirected” meditation of SN 47.10.

sn22.80:8.5.pli: Yāvañcidaṃ, bhikkhave, alameva animitto samādhi bhāvetuṃ.
sn22.80:8.5.eng: This is quite enough motivation to develop signless immersion.

sn22.80:8.6.pli: Animitto, bhikkhave, samādhi bhāvito bahulīkato mahapphalo hoti mahānisaṃso.
sn22.80:8.6.eng: When signless immersion is developed and cultivated it is very fruitful and beneficial.

sn22.80:9.2.eng: Views favoring existence and views favoring nonexistence.

sn22.80:9.3.pli: Tatra kho, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako iti paṭisañcikkhati:
sn22.80:9.3.eng: A learned noble disciple reflects on this:

sn22.80:9.4.pli: ‘atthi nu kho taṃ kiñci lokasmiṃ yamahaṃ upādiyamāno na vajjavā assan’ti?
sn22.80:9.4.eng: ‘Is there anything in the world that I could grasp without fault?’

sn22.80:9.6.pli: ‘natthi nu kho taṃ kiñci lokasmiṃ yamahaṃ upādiyamāno na vajjavā assaṃ.
sn22.80:9.6.eng: ‘There’s nothing in the world that I could grasp without fault.

sn22.80:9.7.eng: For in grasping I would grasp only at form, feeling,

sn22.80:9.10.eng: That grasping of mine would be a condition for continued existence.
sn22.80:9.10.comm: Here the text integrates the aggregates with dependent origination. The aggregates are grasped by way of desire, but they also form the basis of theories of self, which is central to dependent origination (see SN 12.2:6.3 and note).

sn22.80:9.11.eng: Continued existence is a requirement for rebirth.

sn22.80:9.12.eng: Rebirth is a requirement for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be.

sn22.80:9.13.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.’

sn22.80:10.4.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn22.80:10.4.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn22.80:10.6.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
sn22.80:10.6.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

sn22.80:10.7.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

sn22.80:10.15.eng: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn22.81:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kosambiyaṃ viharati ghositārāme.
sn22.81:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kosambī, in Ghosita’s Monastery.

sn22.81:1.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya kosambiṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
sn22.81:1.2.eng: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Kosambī for alms.

sn22.81:1.3.pli: Kosambiyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto sāmaṃ senāsanaṃ saṃsāmetvā pattacīvaramādāya anāmantetvā upaṭṭhāke anapaloketvā bhikkhusaṅghaṃ eko adutiyo cārikaṃ pakkāmi.
sn22.81:1.3.eng: After the meal, on his return from almsround, he set his lodgings in order himself. Taking his bowl and robe, without informing his attendants or taking leave of the mendicant Saṅgha, he set out to go wandering alone, with no companion.
sn22.81:1.3.comm: This story is expanded at Ud 4.5, where the Buddha reflects on how crowded he is with people all around. But the full story is told in the Vinaya at Kd 10. The local Saṅgha at Kosambī had fallen into dispute over a trivial matter. They would not settle it even at the Buddha’s urging, so he left.

sn22.81:2.1.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu acirapakkantassa bhagavato yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavoca:
sn22.81:2.1.eng: Then, not long after the Buddha had left, one of the mendicants went to Venerable Ānanda and told him what had happened.

sn22.81:2.2.pli: “esāvuso ānanda, bhagavā sāmaṃ senāsanaṃ saṃsāmetvā pattacīvaramādāya anāmantetvā upaṭṭhāke anapaloketvā bhikkhusaṅghaṃ eko adutiyo cārikaṃ pakkanto”ti.

sn22.81:2.3.pli: “Yasmiṃ, āvuso, samaye bhagavā sāmaṃ senāsanaṃ saṃsāmetvā pattacīvaramādāya anāmantetvā upaṭṭhāke anapaloketvā bhikkhusaṅghaṃ eko adutiyo cārikaṃ pakkamati, ekova bhagavā tasmiṃ samaye viharitukāmo hoti;
sn22.81:2.3.eng: Ānanda said, “Reverend, when the Buddha leaves like this it means he wants to stay alone.

sn22.81:2.4.pli: na bhagavā tasmiṃ samaye kenaci anubandhitabbo hotī”ti.
sn22.81:2.4.eng: At this time no-one should follow him.”

sn22.81:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā anupubbena cārikaṃ caramāno yena pālileyyakaṃ tadavasari.
sn22.81:3.1.eng: Then the Buddha, traveling stage by stage, arrived at Pārileyyaka,

sn22.81:3.2.pli: Tatra sudaṃ bhagavā pālileyyake viharati bhaddasālamūle.
sn22.81:3.2.eng: where he stayed at the root of a sacred sal tree.
sn22.81:3.2.comm: Linguistically, pārileyyaka means “the place of the son of Parila”. However, the commentary tells at length of how an elephant living in this “protected forest grove” (Ud 4.5:2.4) attended on the Buddha with his friend, the monkey Madhuda, bringing the Buddha food and caring for his every need. The elephant was named Pārileyya (Ja 488:24.1), and the forest Pārileyyaka after him.

sn22.81:3.3.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā ānandena saddhiṃ sammodiṃsu.
sn22.81:3.3.eng: Then several mendicants went up to Venerable Ānanda and exchanged greetings with him.

sn22.81:3.4.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn22.81:3.4.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side and said to him,

sn22.81:3.5.pli: “cirassutā kho no, āvuso ānanda, bhagavato sammukhā dhammī kathā;
sn22.81:3.5.eng: “Reverend, it’s been a long time since we’ve heard a Dhamma talk from the Buddha.

sn22.81:3.6.pli: icchāma mayaṃ, āvuso ānanda, bhagavato sammukhā dhammiṃ kathaṃ sotun”ti.
sn22.81:3.6.eng: We wish to hear a Dhamma talk from the Buddha.”

sn22.81:4.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando tehi bhikkhūhi saddhiṃ yena pālileyyakaṃ bhaddasālamūlaṃ yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
sn22.81:4.1.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda together with those mendicants went to Pārileyyaka to see the Buddha. They bowed and sat down to one side,

sn22.81:4.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinne kho te bhikkhū bhagavā dhammiyā kathāya sandassesi samādapesi samuttejesi sampahaṃsesi.
sn22.81:4.2.eng: and the Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired them with a Dhamma talk.

sn22.81:4.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññatarassa bhikkhuno evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
sn22.81:4.3.eng: Now at that time one of the monks had the thought,

sn22.81:4.4.pli: “kathaṃ nu kho jānato kathaṃ passato anantarā āsavānaṃ khayo hotī”ti?
sn22.81:4.4.eng: “How do you know and see in order to end the defilements without delay?”
sn22.81:4.4.comm: Anantara is a synonym for akālika, sandiṭṭhika, and diṭṭheva dhamme, all of which mean “in the present life, without delay or interim”.

sn22.81:4.5.pli: Atha kho bhagavā tassa bhikkhuno cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya bhikkhū āmantesi:
sn22.81:4.5.eng: Then the Buddha, knowing that monk’s train of thought, addressed the mendicants:

sn22.81:4.7.eng: I’ve analytically taught the four kinds of mindfulness meditation,

sn22.81:4.9.eng: the four bases of psychic power,

sn22.81:4.14.pli: Evaṃ vicayaso desito, bhikkhave, mayā dhammo.
sn22.81:4.14.eng: That’s how I’ve taught the Dhamma analytically.

sn22.81:4.15.pli: Evaṃ vicayaso desite kho, bhikkhave, mayā dhamme atha ca panidhekaccassa bhikkhuno evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
sn22.81:4.15.eng: Though I’ve taught the Dhamma analytically, still a certain mendicant present here has this thought:

sn22.81:4.16.pli: ‘kathaṃ nu kho jānato kathaṃ passato anantarā āsavānaṃ khayo hotī’ti?
sn22.81:4.16.eng: ‘How do you know and see in order to end the defilements without delay?’

sn22.81:5.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, jānato kathaṃ passato anantarā āsavānaṃ khayo hoti?
sn22.81:5.1.eng: And how, mendicants, do you know and see in order to end the defilements without delay?

sn22.81:5.2.pli: Idha bhikkhave, assutavā puthujjano ariyānaṃ adassāvī ariyadhammassa akovido ariyadhamme avinīto, sappurisānaṃ adassāvī sappurisadhammassa akovido sappurisadhamme avinīto
sn22.81:5.2.eng: Take an unlearned ordinary person who has not seen the noble ones, and is neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve not seen true persons, and are neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the true persons.

sn22.81:5.4.pli: Yā kho pana sā, bhikkhave, samanupassanā saṅkhāro so.
sn22.81:5.4.eng: But that regarding is just a conditioned phenomenon.

sn22.81:5.5.pli: So pana saṅkhāro kiṃnidāno kiṃsamudayo kiṃjātiko kiṃpabhavo?
sn22.81:5.5.eng: And what’s the source, origin, birthplace, and inception of that conditioned phenomenon?

sn22.81:5.6.pli: Avijjāsamphassajena, bhikkhave, vedayitena phuṭṭhassa assutavato puthujjanassa uppannā taṇhā;
sn22.81:5.6.eng: When an unlearned ordinary person is struck by feelings born of contact with ignorance, craving arises.

sn22.81:5.7.eng: That conditioned phenomenon is born from that.

sn22.81:5.8.pli: Iti kho, bhikkhave, sopi saṅkhāro anicco saṅkhato paṭiccasamuppanno.
sn22.81:5.8.eng: So that conditioned phenomenon is impermanent, conditioned, and dependently originated.

sn22.81:5.10.pli: Sāpi vedanā, sopi phasso anicco saṅkhato paṭiccasamuppanno.

sn22.81:5.11.eng: and that ignorance are also impermanent, conditioned, and dependently originated.

sn22.81:5.12.pli: Evampi kho, bhikkhave, jānato evaṃ passato anantarā āsavānaṃ khayo hoti.
sn22.81:5.12.eng: That’s how you should know and see in order to end the defilements without delay.

sn22.81:7.7.pli: Iti kho, bhikkhave, sopi saṅkhāro anicco saṅkhato paṭiccasamuppanno.

sn22.81:8.7.pli: Iti kho, bhikkhave, sopi saṅkhāro anicco saṅkhato paṭiccasamuppanno.

sn22.81:9.2.pli: api ca kho vedanaṃ attato samanupassati, api ca kho vedanāvantaṃ attānaṃ samanupassati, api ca kho attani vedanaṃ samanupassati, api ca kho vedanāya attānaṃ samanupassati;
sn22.81:9.2.eng: But they regard feeling as self …

sn22.81:9.4.pli: api ca kho saṅkhāre attato samanupassati, api ca kho saṅkhāravantaṃ attānaṃ samanupassati, api ca kho attani saṅkhāre samanupassati, api ca kho saṅkhāresu attānaṃ samanupassati;

sn22.81:9.5.pli: api ca kho viññāṇaṃ attato samanupassati, api ca kho viññāṇavantaṃ attānaṃ, api ca kho attani viññāṇaṃ, api ca kho viññāṇasmiṃ attānaṃ samanupassati.

sn22.81:9.6.pli: Yā kho pana sā, bhikkhave, samanupassanā saṅkhāro so.
sn22.81:9.6.eng: But that regarding is just a conditioned phenomenon.

sn22.81:9.7.eng: And what’s the source of that conditioned phenomenon?

sn22.81:9.8.pli: Avijjāsamphassajena, bhikkhave, vedayitena phuṭṭhassa assutavato puthujjanassa uppannā taṇhā;
sn22.81:9.8.eng: When an unlearned ordinary person is struck by feelings born of contact with ignorance, craving arises.

sn22.81:9.9.eng: That conditioned phenomenon is born from that.

sn22.81:9.10.pli: Iti kho, bhikkhave, sopi saṅkhāro anicco saṅkhato paṭiccasamuppanno.
sn22.81:9.10.eng: So that conditioned phenomenon is impermanent, conditioned, and dependently originated.

sn22.81:9.14.eng: and that ignorance are also impermanent, conditioned, and dependently originated.

sn22.81:9.15.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, jānato evaṃ passato anantarā āsavānaṃ khayo hoti.
sn22.81:9.15.eng: That’s how you should know and see in order to end the defilements without delay.

sn22.81:10.1.pli: Na heva kho rūpaṃ attato samanupassati,

sn22.81:10.6.eng: Still, they have such a view:

sn22.81:10.7.pli: ‘so attā so loko, so pecca bhavissāmi nicco dhuvo sassato avipariṇāmadhammo’ti.
sn22.81:10.7.eng: ‘The self and the cosmos are one and the same. After death I will be that, permanent, everlasting, eternal, and imperishable.’
sn22.81:10.7.comm: The repeated demonstrative pronouns in the Pali so loko so attā (literally, “This is the cosmos, this is the self”) affirm an emphatic and absolute identity: “The cosmos and the self are one and the same”. As the central thesis of the Upaniṣads, it has a lexical parallel at Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.4.22, which argues for the renunciate life: “What can descendants do for those for whom the self and the cosmos are one and the same?” (ayamātmāyaṁ loka). Similarly, BU 1.2.7 says of the sacrificial fire as the sun, “these worlds are its self” (tasyeme lokā ātmānaḥ), and BU 1.4.15 says one should “worship the cosmos as the self”(ātmānam eva lokam upāsīta). See also the last words of a father to his son at 1.5.17: “You are divinity, you are the sacrifice, you are the cosmos” (tvaṁ brahma tvaṁ yajñas tvaṁ loka).

sn22.81:10.8.pli: Yā kho pana sā, bhikkhave, sassatadiṭṭhi saṅkhāro so.
sn22.81:10.8.eng: But that eternalist view is just a conditioned phenomenon.

sn22.81:10.9.eng: And what’s the source of that conditioned phenomenon? …

sn22.81:10.10.pli: evampi kho, bhikkhave, jānato evaṃ passato anantarā āsavānaṃ khayo hoti.
sn22.81:10.10.eng: That’s how you should know and see in order to end the defilements without delay.

sn22.81:11.1.pli: Na heva kho rūpaṃ attato samanupassati,

sn22.81:11.6.eng: Nor do they have such a view:

sn22.81:11.7.pli: ‘so attā so loko, so pecca bhavissāmi nicco dhuvo sassato avipariṇāmadhammo’ti.
sn22.81:11.7.eng: ‘The self and the cosmos are one and the same. After death I will be that, permanent, everlasting, eternal, and imperishable.’

sn22.81:11.8.eng: Still, they have such a view:

sn22.81:11.9.pli: ‘no cassaṃ no ca me siyā nābhavissaṃ na me bhavissatī’ti.
sn22.81:11.9.eng: ‘I might not be, and it might not be mine. I will not be, and it will not be mine.’

sn22.81:11.10.pli: Yā kho pana sā, bhikkhave, ucchedadiṭṭhi saṅkhāro so.
sn22.81:11.10.eng: But that annihilationist view is just a conditioned phenomenon.

sn22.81:11.11.pli: So pana saṅkhāro kiṃnidāno kiṃsamudayo kiṃjātiko kiṃpabhavo?
sn22.81:11.11.eng: And what’s the source of that conditioned phenomenon? …

sn22.81:12.1.pli: Na heva kho rūpaṃ attato samanupassati, na vedanaṃ …

sn22.81:12.5.eng: Nor do they have such a view:

sn22.81:12.6.eng: ‘The self and the cosmos are one and the same. After death I will be that, permanent, everlasting, eternal, and imperishable.’

sn22.81:12.9.eng: Still, they have doubts and uncertainties. They’re undecided about the true teaching.

sn22.81:12.10.pli: Yā kho pana sā, bhikkhave, kaṅkhitā vicikicchitā aniṭṭhaṅgatatā saddhamme saṅkhāro so.
sn22.81:12.10.eng: That doubt and uncertainty, the indecision about the true teaching, is just a conditioned phenomenon.

sn22.81:12.11.pli: So pana saṅkhāro kiṃnidāno kiṃsamudayo kiṃjātiko kiṃpabhavo?
sn22.81:12.11.eng: And what’s the source of that conditioned phenomenon?

sn22.81:12.12.pli: Avijjāsamphassajena, bhikkhave, vedayitena phuṭṭhassa assutavato puthujjanassa uppannā taṇhā;
sn22.81:12.12.eng: When an unlearned ordinary person is struck by feelings born of contact with ignorance, craving arises.

sn22.81:12.13.eng: That conditioned phenomenon is born from that.

sn22.81:12.14.eng: So that conditioned phenomenon is impermanent, conditioned, and dependently originated.

sn22.81:12.18.eng: and that ignorance are also impermanent, conditioned, and dependently originated.

sn22.81:12.19.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, jānato evaṃ passato anantarā āsavānaṃ khayo hotī”ti.
